question: Question 1 Which one of the following is correct?
solution: [latex]\lim_{x \to 0}\left ( \frac{\sin 4x}{\sin 2x} \right )=\lim_{x \to 0}\left ( \frac{\frac{\sin 4x}{x}}{\frac{\sin 2x}{x}} \right )=\frac{4}{2}=2[/latex] and [latex]\lim_{x \to 0}\left ( \frac{\tan x}{x} \right )=1[/latex]

question: Question 2 Consider a two-dimensional flow through isotropic soil along x direction and z direction. If h is the hydraulic head, the Laplace's equation of continuity is expressed as
solution: The Laplace's equation of continuity for two dimensional flow in a soil is expressed as: [latex]k_x\frac{\partial^2 h}{\partial x^2}+k_z\frac{\partial^2 h}{\partial z^2}=0[/latex]... for anisotropic soil [latex][k_x\neq k_z][/latex] : [latex]\frac{\partial^2 h}{\partial x^2}+\frac{\partial^2 h}{\partial z^2}=0[/latex]... for isotropic soil [latex][k_x = k_z][/latex]

options.B: [latex]\frac{\partial h}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial h}{\partial x}\frac{\partial h}{\partial z}+\frac{\partial h}{\partial z}=0[/latex]
options.D: [latex]\frac{\partial^2 h}{\partial x^2}+\frac{\partial^2 h}{\partial x \partial z}+\frac{\partial^2 h}{\partial z^2}=0[/latex]

question: Question 3 A simple mass-spring oscillatory system consists of a mass m, suspended from a spring of stiffness k. Considering z as the displacementof the system at any time t, the equation of motion for the free vibration of the system is [latex]m\ddot{z}+kz=0[/latex]. The natural frequency of the system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} m\ddot{z}+kz&=0 \\ \ddot{z}+\frac{k}{m}z&=0 \\ \text{Comparing with} \\ \ddot{z}+\omega _n^2 z&=0 \\ \text{We get}\;\; \omega _n&=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 4 For a small value of h, the Taylor series expansion for [latex]f(x+h)[/latex] is
solution: We know that Taylor series for small h of f(x + h) is, [latex]f(x+h)=f(x)+hf'(x)+\frac{h^2}{2!}f''(x)+\frac{h^3}{3!}f'''(x)+...[/latex]

question: Question 5 A plane truss is shown in the figure Which one of the options contains ONLY zero force members in the truss?
solution: So zero force members are FI, FG, RS, PR

question: Question 6 An element is subjected to biaxial normal tensile strains of 0.0030 and 0.0020. The normal strain in the plane of maximum shear strain is
solution: [latex]\varepsilon _x=0.0030[/latex] [latex] \varepsilon _y=0.0020 [/latex] Normal strain in the plane of maximum shear strain [latex]\varepsilon _{avg}=\frac{\varepsilon _x+\varepsilon _y}{2}=\frac{0.0030+0.0020}{2}=0.0025[/latex]

question: Question 7 Consider the pin-jointed plane truss shown in the figure. Let [latex]R_P,R_Q[/latex] and [latex]R_R[/latex] denote the vertical reactions (upward positive) applied by the supports at P, Q, and R, respectively, on the truss. The correct combination of ([latex]R_P,R_Q,R_R[/latex])is represented by
solution: Adopting method of sections and taking LHS of the section [latex]\begin{aligned} &\Sigma F_y= 0\\ &R_P=30kN \\ &\text{For complete truss,} \\ &\Sigma M_R =0 \\ &9R_P-30 \times 6 -R_Q \times 3=0 \\ &R_Q=30kN(\downarrow ) \\ &\text{Taking RHS of section,} \\ &\Sigma F_y=0\Rightarrow R_R=-R_Q \\ &\text{Thus},\;\; R_Q= 30kN(\downarrow )\\ &R_R=30kN(\uparrow ) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 8 Assuming that there is no possibility of shear buckling in the web, the maximum reduction permitted by IS 800-2007 in the (low-shear) design bending strength of a semi-compact steel section due to high shear is
solution: As per IS 800 : 2007 For semi compact section (i) In low shear case ([latex]V \leq 0.6 V_d[/latex]) [latex]M_d = Z_ef_y/\gamma _{mo}[/latex] (ii) In high shear case ([latex]V \gt 0.6 V_d[/latex]) [latex]M_d = Z_ef_y/\gamma _{mo}[/latex] So reduction is zero.

options.D: governed by the area of the flange

question: Question 9 In the reinforced beam section shown in the figure, the nominal cover provided at the bottom of the beam as per IS 456-2000, is
solution: Nominal cover = Effective cover [latex]-\frac{\phi _m}{2}-\phi _{st}[/latex] [latex]=50-\frac{16}{2}-12=30mm[/latex] Nominal cover is the distance from extreme concrete fbre to the surface of stirrup.

question: Question 10 The interior angles of four triangles are given below: Which of the triangles are ill-conditioned and should be avoided in Triangulation surveys?
solution: For an ill conditioned traingle in triangulation survey, any angle can be less than [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex], and can be greater than [latex]120^{\circ}[/latex]. For traingles Q and S, the above condition is valid.

question: Question 11 The coefficient of average rolling friction of a road is [latex]f_r[/latex] and its grade is +G%. If the grade of this road is doubled, what will be the percentage change in the braking distance (for the design vehicle to come to a stop) measured along the horizontal (assume all other parameters are kept unchanged)?
solution: Percentage change in Braking Distance [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\left ( \frac{L_{B_1}-L_{B_2} }{L_{B_1}} \right ) \times 100\\ \%\Delta L_B&=\frac{\frac{V^2}{254[f_r+0.01G]}-\frac{V^2}{254[f_r+0.02G]}}{\frac{V^2}{254[f_r+0.01G]}}\\ &=\frac{f_r+0.02G-f_r-0.01G}{(f_r+0.01G)(f_r+0.02G)} \times (f_r+0.01G)\\ \%\Delta L_B&=\left ( \frac{0.01G}{f_r+0.02G} \times 100 \right ) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 12 An isolated concrete pavement slab of length L is resting on a frictionless base. The temperature of the top and bottom fibre of the slab are [latex]T_t \; and \; T_b[/latex], respectively. Given: the coefficient of thermal expansion [latex]=\alpha[/latex] and the elastic modulus =E. Assuming [latex]T_t \gt T_b[/latex] and the unit weight of concrete as zero, the maximum thermal stress is calculated as
solution: Due to frictionless, thermal stress developed in concrete pavement slab is zero [latex]\sigma _{th}=0[/latex]

question: Question 13 In a rectangular channel, the ratio of the velocity head to the flow depth for critical flow condition, is
solution: For Critical flow [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Velocity Head is equal to half of hydraulic depth. [latex]\frac{V^2}{2g}=\frac{D}{2}[/latex] for rectangular channel D = y [latex]\frac{\frac{V^2}{2g}}{y}=\frac{1}{2}[/latex]

question: Question 14 If the path of an irrigation canal is below the bed level of a natural stream, the type of cross-drainage structure provided is
solution: Irrigation canal below the bed level of a natural stream [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Super passage

question: Question 15 A catchment may be idealised as a rectangle. There are three rain gauges located inside the catchment at arbitrary locations. The average precipitation over the catchment is estimated by two methods: (i) Arithmetic mean ([latex]P_A[/latex]), and (ii) Thiessen polygon ([latex]P_T[/latex]). Which one of the followingstatements is correct?
solution:
The result from Thiessen polygon method is more accurate than arithmetic mean method.
But there is no any close relationship between values obtained by Thiessen polygon method and Arithmetic mean method. Therefore, there is no any relation between [latex]P_A[/latex] and [latex]P_T[/latex].

options.D: There is no definite relationship between [latex]P_A \; and \; P_T[/latex]

question: Question 16 A retaining wall of height H with smooth vertical backface supports a backfill inclined at an angle [latex]\beta[/latex] with the horizontal. The backfill consists of cohesionless soil having angle of internal friction [latex]\phi[/latex]. If the active lateral thrust acting on the wall is [latex]P_a[/latex], which one of the following statements is TRUE?

options.A: [latex]P_a[/latex] acts at a height H/2 from the base of the wall and at an angle  [latex]\beta[/latex] with the horizontal
options.B: [latex]P_a[/latex] acts at a height H/2 from the base of the wall and at an angle  [latex]\phi[/latex] with the horizontal
options.C: [latex]P_a[/latex] acts at a height H/3 from the base of the wall and at an angle  [latex]\beta[/latex] with the horizontal
options.D: [latex]P_a[/latex] acts at a height H/3 from the base of the wall and at an angle  [latex]\phi[/latex] with the horizontal

question: Question 17 In a soil specimen, the total stress, effective stress, hydraulic gradient and critical hydraulic gradient are [latex]\sigma ,\sigma ',i, \; and \; i_c[/latex], respectively. For initiation of quicksand condition, which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution: Quick sand condition occurs if [latex]\sigma '=0[/latex] and [latex]i=i_c[/latex]

question: Question 18 Which one of the following is a secondary pollutant?
solution: Ozone is a dangerous secondary air contaminant.

question: Question 19 For a given loading on a rectangular plain concrete beam with an overall depth of 500 mm, the compressive strain and tensile strain developed at the extreme fibers are of the same magnitude of [latex]2.5 \times 10^{-4}[/latex]. The curvature in the beam cross-section (in [latex]m^{-1}[/latex], round off to 3 decimal places), is ____
solution: Simple bending equation [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{m}{I}&=\frac{f}{y}=\frac{E}{R} \\ \frac{1}{R}&=\frac{f}{E}\cdot \frac{1}{y} \\ &=\frac{\varepsilon }{y}=\frac{2.5 \times 10^{-4}}{(0.5/2)}=0.001m^{-1} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 20 A completely mixed dilute suspension of sand particles having diameters 0.25, 0.35, 0.40, 0.45 and 0.50 mm are filled in a transparent glass column of diameter 10 cm and height 2.50 m. The suspension is allowed to settle without any disturbance. It is observed that all particles of diameter 0.35 mm settle to the bottom of the column in 30 s. For the same period of 30 s, the percentage removal (round off to integer value) of particles of diameters 0.45 and 0.50 mm from the suspension is ____
solution:
Since sand particle of size 0.35 mm settles to the bottom of the column in 30 sec
particles having size greater than 0.35 mm i.e. 0.45 and 0.50 mm will also settle in
suspension at the bottom of column by 100% in 30 sec, infact these bigger sized particle
will settle by 100% in less than 30 sec. So answer is 100%.

question: Question 21 The maximum number of vehicles observed in any five minute period during the peak hour is 160. If the total flow in the peak hour is 1000 vehicles, the five minute peak hour factor (round off to 2 decimal places) is ___
solution: Given actual flow in peak hour, [latex]q_{actual}=10^3 \;\text{veh/hr}[/latex] peak 5 min rate = 160 veh/5min Peak (5min)rate volume, [latex]q_{\text{peak rate}}=\frac{160}{\frac{5}{60}} =1920\;\text{veh/hr}[/latex] Therefore, peak hourly factor (PHF) for 5 min is [latex]PHF_5=\frac{q_{\text{actual}}}{q_{\text{peak rate}}}=\frac{10^3}{1920}=0.52083\approx 0.52[/latex]

question: Question 22 A circular duct carrying water gradually contracts from a diameter of 30 cm to 15 cm. The figure shows the arrangement of differential manometer attached to the duct When the water flows, the differential manometer shows a deflection of 8 cm of mercury (Hg). The values of specific gravity of mercury and water are 13.6 and 1.0, respectively. Consider the acceleration due to gravity, [latex]g=9.81m/s^2[/latex]. Assuming frictionless flow, the flow rate (in [latex]m^3/s[/latex], round off to 3 decimal places) through the duct is ____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q&=\frac{A_1A_2}{\sqrt{A_1^2-A_2^2}}\sqrt{2gh} \\ h&=x\left [ \frac{\rho H_g}{\rho _w}-1 \right ] \\ &=0.08(13.6-1)=1.008m \;\;(A_1=4A_2) \\ Q&=\frac{4A_2 \times A_2}{\sqrt{16A_2^2-A_2^2}}\times \sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 1.008} \\ &= \frac{4}{\sqrt{15}} \times A_2 \times \sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 1.008}\\ &= \frac{4}{\sqrt{15}} \times \frac{\pi}{4}(0.15)^2 \times \sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 1.008} \\ Q&=0.081m^3/s \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 23 The probability that the annual maximum flood discharge will exceed 25000 [latex]m^3/s[/latex], at least once in next 5 years is found to be 0.25. The return period of this flood event (in years, round off to 1 decimal place) is ____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Risk} &=1-q^n \\ 0.25&=1-q^5 \\ q&=0.944087 \\ 1-p&=0.944087 \\ 1-\frac{1}{T}&=0.944087 \\ T&\simeq 17.9 \; \text{years} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 24 A soil has specific gravity of its solids equal to 2.65. The mass density of water is 1000 [latex]kg/m^3[/latex]. Considering zero air voids and 10% moisture content of the soil sample, the dry density (in [latex]kg/m^3[/latex], round off to 1 decimal place) would be _______
solution: [latex]G_s=2.65,[/latex] [latex] \gamma _w=1000kg/m^3[/latex] Degree of saturation, S = 100% (Zero air voids) w = 10% The dry density corresponding to zero air voids or 100% saturation, [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma _d&= \frac{\gamma _wG_s}{1+wG_s}\\ &= \frac{1000\times 2.65}{1+0.1 \times 2.65}\\ &= 2094.9kg/m^3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 25 A concentrated load of 500 kN is applied on an elastic half space. The ratio of the increase in vertical normal stress at depths of 2m and 4m along the point of the loading, as per Boussinesq's theory, would be ___
solution: As per Boussinesq's equation, The vertical stress below the ground level at a depth, Z, vertically below the load, [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma _Z&=\frac{3}{2\pi}\frac{Q}{Z^2}\\ \sigma _Z &\propto \frac{1}{Z^2}\\ \therefore \;\; \frac{\sigma _{Z_1}}{\sigma _{Z_2}}&=\left [ \frac{Z_2}{Z_1} \right ]^2\\ &=\left [ \frac{4}{2} \right ]^2=4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 26 Which one of the following is NOT a correct statement?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Let}\;y &=\sqrt[x]{x}\;\;x \gt 0 \\ y&=x^{\frac{1}{x}} \\ \ln y&=\ln x^{\frac{1}{x}} \\ \ln y &=\frac{1}{x} \ln x \\ \frac{1}{y} \frac{dy}{dx}&=\frac{1}{x^2}-\frac{\ln x}{x^2} \\ \frac{1}{y} \frac{dy}{dx}&=\frac{1}{x^2}(1-\ln x) \\ \frac{dy}{dx}&= \frac{y}{x^2}(1-\ln x)\\ \text{put}\;\; \frac{dy}{dx}&=0\Rightarrow \frac{y}{x^2}(1-\ln x)=0 \\ \Rightarrow \; x&=e \\ \text{Now,}\;\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} &=\frac{-y}{x^3}-\frac{2y}{x^3}(1- \ln x)+\frac{1}{x^2}(1-\ln x)\frac{dy}{dx} \\ \text{At}\; x &=e, \\ \frac{d^2y}{dx^2}&=\left ( \frac{-y}{x^3} \right )_{x=e}-\frac{2y}{x^3}(1-\ln e)+\frac{1}{x^2}(1- \ln e)\frac{dy}{dx} \\ &= \left ( \frac{-x^{\frac{1}{x}}}{x} \right )_{at\; x=e}\\ &=\frac{-e^{\frac{1}{e}}}{e}=0\\ \frac{d^2y}{dx^2}\; & \text{has maximum at }\; x=e \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: The function [latex]\sqrt[x]{x},(x \gt 0)[/latex], has the global maxima at [latex]x=e[/latex]
options.B: The function [latex]\sqrt[x]{x},(x \gt 0)[/latex], has the global minima at [latex]x=e[/latex]
options.C: The function [latex]x^3[/latex] has neither global minima nor global maxima
options.D: The function |x| has the global minima at x=0

question: Question 27 A one-dimensional domain is discretized into N sub-domains of width [latex]\Delta x[/latex] with node numbers i=0,1, 2, 3,...,N. If the time scale is discretized in steps of [latex]\Delta t[/latex], the forward-time and centered-space finite difference approximation at [latex]i^{th}[/latex] node and [latex]n^{th}[/latex] time step, for the partial differential equation [latex]\frac{\partial v}{\partial t}=\beta \frac{\partial^2 v}{\partial x^2}[/latex] is
solution: Given [latex]\frac{\partial V}{\partial t}=\beta \frac{\partial^2 V}{\partial x^2}[/latex] The centred space finite difference approximation at [latex]i^{th}[/latex] node [latex]n^{th}[/latex] time step is [latex]\frac{V_i^{n+1}-V_i^n}{\Delta t}=\beta \left [ \frac{V_{i+1}^n -2V_i^n +V_{i-1}^n}{(\Delta X)^2} \right ][/latex]

question: Question 28 A rectangular open channel has a width of 5 m and a bed slope of 0.001. For a uniform flow of depth 2 m, the velocity is 2 m/s. The Manning's roughness coefficient for the channel is
solution: Given, [latex]\begin{aligned} V&= 2 m/sec, \; S=0.001\\ A&=5 \times 2=10m^2\\ P&=5+2+2=9m\\ & \text{Hydraulic mean radius}\\ (R)&=\frac{A}{P}=\frac{10}{9}\\ V&=\frac{1}{n}R^{2/3}S^{1/2}\\ 2&=\frac{1}{n}\left ( \frac{10}{9} \right )^{2/3}(0.001)^{1/2}\\ n&=0.0169\simeq 0.017 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 29 For the following statements: P: The lateral stress in the soil while being tested in an oedometer is always at-rest. Q: For a perfectly rigid strip footing at deeper depths in a sand deposit, the vertical normal contact stress at the footing edge is greater than that at its centre. R: The corrections for overburden pressure and dilatancy are not applied to measured SPT-N values in case of clay deposits. The correct combination of the statements is
solution:
P: True In the Oedometer test, stress is applied to the soil specimen along the vertical axis, while strain in the horizontal
direction is prevented by the confining ring (a condition of zero lateral strain). Thus it simulates at-rest condition. Q: True For a perfectly rigid footing resting on surface of sand deposit, the contact pressure distribution is zero
at the edges and maximum at centre. However, for a very deep rigid footing on sand, the contact pressure
distribution may tend to become like that of rigid footing on clayey soil, with edge contact stress greater than at
its centre. R: True For cohesive soil, there is no need for overburden pressure correction (Peck et al 1974). For cohesionless soil at
first overburden pressure correction is made, then if it is fine sand or silt under water table with N-value [latex]\gt[/latex] 15,
dilatancy correction is made.

question: Question 30 Consider two functions: [latex]x=\psi ln\phi[/latex] and [latex]y=\phi ln\psi[/latex]. Which one of the following is the correct expression for [latex]\frac{\partial \psi }{\partial x}[/latex]?
solution: Taking the partial derivative with respect to x for the two equations, we get [latex]\begin{aligned} 1&=\frac{\partial \psi }{\partial x}\ln \phi +\frac{\psi }{\phi }\frac{\partial \phi }{\partial x}\\ 0&=\frac{\phi }{\psi }\frac{\partial \psi }{\partial x}+ \ln \psi \frac{\partial \phi }{\partial x} \end{aligned}[/latex] From above two equations, we get [latex]\frac{\partial \psi }{\partial x}=\frac{\ln \psi }{\ln \phi \ln \psi -1}[/latex]

question: Question 31 The cross-section of a built-up wooden beam as shown in the figure is subjected to a vertical shear force of 8 kN. The beam is symmetrical about the neutral axis (N.A.) shown, and the moment of inertia about N.A. is [latex]1.5 \times 10^9 mm^4[/latex]. Considering that the nails at the location P are spaced longitudinally (along the length of the beam) at 60 mm, each of the nails at P will be subjected to the shear force of
solution: Shear stress acting at the joint at which the nail 'P' is resisting the shear. [latex]\begin{aligned} \tau &=\frac{FA\bar{y}}{Ib}\\ &=\frac{(8 \times 10^3)(50 \times 100)(150)}{1.5 \times 10^9 \times 50}\\ &=0.08N/mm^2 \end{aligned}[/latex] The shear force acting on nail at 'P'. [latex]F=\tau (60\times 50)=240N[/latex]

question: Question 32 The rigid-jointed plane frame QRS shown in the figure is subjected to a load P at the joint R. Let the axial deformations in the frame be neglected. If the support S undergoes a settlement of [latex]\Delta =\frac{PL^3}{\beta EI}[/latex], the vertical reaction at the support S will become zero when [latex]\beta[/latex] is equal to
solution: Adopting moment distribution method: Thus, fnal vertical reaction at S (both due [latex]f_0[/latex] sinking and P) [latex]\begin{aligned} R_S&=P-V \\ &= P-\frac{7.5EI}{L^3} \times \frac{PL^3}{\beta EI}\\ R_S&=\frac{P-7.5T}{\beta}\;\;\text{when}\; \beta =\text{ reaction at S = 0} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 33 If the section shown in the figure turns from fully-elastic to fully-plastic, the depth of neutral axis (N.A.), [latex]\bar{y}[/latex], decreases by

Question 34 Sedimentation basin in a water treatment plant is designed for a flow rate of 0.2 [latex]m^3/s[/latex]. The basin is rectangular with a length of 32m, width of 8m, and depth of 4m. Assume that the settling velocity of these particles is governed by the Stokes' law. Given: density of the particles = 2.5 [latex]g/cm^3[/latex]; density of water = 1 [latex]g/cm^3[/latex]; dynamic viscosity of water = 0.01 g/(cm.s); gravitational acceleration = 980 [latex]cm/s^2[/latex]. If the incoming water contains particles of diameter 25 [latex]\mu m[/latex](spherical and uniform), the removal efficiency of these particles is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q&=0.2m^3/sec,\; L=32m\\ B&=8m,\; H=4m\\ \rho _p&=2.5gm/cc=2500kg/m^3\\ \rho _w&=1gm/cc=1000kg/m^3\\ \mu &=0.01gm/cm-sec=1 \times 10^{-3}kg/m-sec\\ d&=25\mu m=25 \times 10^{-6}m\\ g&=980cm/sec^2=9.8m/sec^2\\ v_0&=\frac{Q}{A_s}=\frac{Q}{L \times B}\\ &=\frac{0.2}{32 \times 8}=7.8125 \times 10^{-4}m/sec\\ v_s&=\frac{g(\rho _p-\rho _w)d^2}{18\mu }\\ &=\frac{9.8(2500-1000)\times (25 \times 10^{-6})^2}{18 \times (1 \times 10^{-3})}\\ &=5.1041 \times 10^{-4}m/sec\\ \eta &=\frac{v_s}{v_0}\times 100\\ &=\frac{5.1041 \times 10^{-4}}{7.8125 \times 10^{-4}}\times 100\\ &=65.33\%\simeq 65\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 35 A survey line was measured to be 285.5 m with a tape having a nominal length of 30 m. On checking, the true length of the tape was found to be 0.05 m too short. If the line lay on a slope of 1 in 10, the reduced length (horizontal length) of the line for plotting of survey work would be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L&=30m, \; L'=30-0.05=29.95m\\ \therefore \;\;& \; \text{Correct Length}\\ l&=l' \times \frac{l'}{L}\\ &=285.5 \times \frac{29.95}{30}=285.024m\\ D&=l \cos \theta \\ \cos \theta &=\frac{10}{\sqrt{10^2+1^2}}=0.995\\ \therefore \;D \;&\; =\text{ correct Horizontal length }\\ &=l\cos \theta \\ &=285.024 \times 0.9950\\ &=283.6m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 A 16 mm thick gusset plate is connected to the 12 mm thick flange plate of an I-section using fillet welds on both sides as shown in the figure. The gusset plate is subjected to a point load of 350 kN acting at a distance of 100 mm from the flange plate. Size of fillet weld is 10 mm. The maximum resultant stress (in MPa, round off to 1 decimalplace) on the fillet weld along the vertical plane would be ____
solution: Direct concentrated load (P) = 350 kN Eccentricity (e) = 100 mm Depth of weld ([latex]d_w[/latex]) at each face = 500 mm Size of weld (S) = 10 mm Throat thickness of weld ([latex]t_t[/latex]) = 0.7S = 7 mm It is a case of combined shear (P) and Bending moment (M = P.e) Shear stress acting on weld due to direct shear force P, [latex]\begin{aligned} (q)&=\frac{P}{A_w} \\ &= \frac{P}{2d_wt_t}\\ &=\frac{350 \times 10^3}{2 \times 500 \times 7}=50MPa \end{aligned}[/latex] Bending normal stress acting at [latex]i^{th}[/latex] point from Neutral axis [latex][f_i]=\frac{M}{I}y_i[/latex] Maximum bending stress at extreme point in weld [latex]\begin{aligned} [f]&=\frac{M}{I}y_{max} \\ &= \frac{Pe}{2t_t \frac{d_w^3}{12}} \times y_{max}\\ &= \frac{350 \times 10^3 \times 100}{2 \times 7 \times \frac{(500)^3}{12}} \times 250\\ &= 60MPa \end{aligned}[/latex] As per IS800:2007. Maximum resultant stress an equivalent stress in fllet weld due to combined shear and bending stress [latex]\begin{aligned} (f_{eq})&=\sqrt{f^2+3q^2} \\ &= \sqrt{60^2+3 \times 50^2}\\ &=105.3MPa \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 37 The network of a small construction project awarded to a contractor is shown in the following figure. The normal duration, crash duration, normal cost, and crash cost of all the activities are shown in the table. The indirect cost incurred by the contractor is INR 5000 per day. If the project is targeted for completion in 16 days, the total cost(in INR) to be incurred by the contractor would be _______
solution:
Indirect cost = Rs. 5000 Crashing possibility = 18 - 17 = 1 day To reduce the project duration by 1 day, the following options available. Best option : Crashing 'R' by 1 day. After crashing 'R' by 1 day, the new network is as for follows. The reduce the project duration by 1 day After crashing Q & R by 1 day, the new network is as follows. Total project cost = Total normal cost + crashing cost of 'R' by 1 day + crashing cost of Q & R by 1 day +
Indirect cost/day ? Project duration = 15000 + 6000 + 8000 + 7000 + 6000 + 4000 + 20000 + 750 ? 1 + 2750 x 1 + 5000 x 16
= 1,49,500 /-

question: Question 38 A box measuring 50 cmx50cmx50cm is filled to the top with dry coarse aggregate of mass 187.5 kg. The water absorption and specific gravity of the aggregate are 0.5% and 2.5, respectively. The maximum quantity of water (in kg, round off to 2 decimal places) required to fill the box completely is_______
solution: Total volume of Box [latex]=0.5 \times 0.5\times 0.5=0.125m^3[/latex] wt of aggregates = 187.5 kg sp. gravity = 2.5 Unit weight [latex]=2.5 \times 9.81=24.525kN/m^3[/latex] wt of water absorbed [latex]=\frac{0.5}{100}\times 187.5=0.9375kg[/latex] vol of aggregate [latex]=\frac{187.5 \times 9.81}{1000 \times 24.525}=0.075m^3[/latex] volume of voids [latex]=0.125-0.075=0.05m^3[/latex] wt of water in voids [latex]=0.05 \times 1000=50kg[/latex] wt of water required to fill the box [latex]= 50 + 0.9375 = 50.94 kg[/latex]

question: Question 39 A portal frame shown in figure has a hinge support at joint P and a roller support at joint R. A point load of 50 kN is acting at joint R in the horizontal direction. The flexural rigidity, EI, of each member is 10 [latex]kNm^2[/latex]. Under the applied load, the horizontal displacement (in mm, round off to 1 decimal place) of joint R would be _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma M_p&=0\;\;[\text{Take clockwise as positive}]\\ R_R \times 5-50 \times 10&=0\\ R_R&=-100kN(\downarrow )\\ R_P&=100kN(\uparrow )\\ EI&=10^6kN-m^2\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Using unit load method: The horizontal displacement at 'R' [latex]\delta _{HR}=\int_{0}^{L}\frac{M_xm_x}{EI}dx[/latex] where [latex]M_x=[/latex] BM at X-X due to real loads [latex]m_x=[/latex] BM at X-X due to vertical unit load applied where we want to find the deflection. [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma M_R &=0\;\;[\text{Take clockwise as positive}]\\ R_P \times 5-1 \times 10&=0\\ R_P&=2kN(\uparrow )\end{aligned}[/latex] Sign conventions: Sagging +ve Hogging -ve [latex]\delta _{HR}=\int_{0}^{5}\frac{200x^2}{10^6}dx+\int_{0}^{10}\frac{50x^2}{10^6}dx=\frac{1}{40}=0.025m=25mm[/latex]

question: Question 40 A sample of air analysed at 0[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and 1 atm pressure is reported to contain 0.02 ppm(parts per million) of [latex]NO_2[/latex]. Assume the gram molecular mass of [latex]NO_2[/latex] as 46 and its volume at 0[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and 1 atm pressure as 22.4 litres per mole. The equivalent [latex]NO_2[/latex] concentration (in microgram per cubic meter, round off to 2 decimalplaces) would be ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} k&=22.4\\ M&=46\\ 0.02\; \text{ppm of}\; NO_2&=0.02 \times \frac{M}{k}\times 10^3 \mu g/m^3\\ &=0.02 \times \frac{46}{22.4}\times 10^{3}\\ &=41.0714\mu g/m^3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 A 0.80 m deep bed of sand filter (length 4 m and width 3 m) is made of uniform particles (diameter = 0.40 mm, specific gravity = 2.65, shape factor = 0.85) with bed porosity of 0.4. The bed has to be backwashed at a flow rate of 3.60 [latex]m^3/min[/latex]. During backwashing, if the terminal settling velocity of sand particles is 0.05 m/s, the expanded bed depth (in m, round off to 2 decimal places) is ________
solution: Given, [latex]\begin{aligned} z &=0.8m \\ n &=0.4m \\ Q_B &=3.6m^3/min \\ &= \frac{3.6}{60}m^3/sec=0.06m^3/sec\\ L&=4m \\ B&= 3m\\ V_B&= \frac{Q_B}{A_s}=\frac{Q_B}{LB}\\ &= \frac{0.06}{4 \times 3}=5 \times 10^{-3}m/sec\\ V_s&= 0.05m/sec\\ V_B&=V_s(n_e)^{4.5} \\ (n_e)^{4.5}&= \frac{V_B}{V_s}=\frac{5 \times 10^{-3}}{0.05}\\ n_e&=\left ( \frac{5 \times 10^{-3}}{0.05} \right )^{\frac{1}{4.5}} \\ &= 0.599\simeq 0.6\\ \frac{z_e}{z}&=\frac{1-n}{1-n_e} \\ z_e &=z\left ( \frac{1-n}{1-n_e} \right ) \\ z_e&=0.8 \times \left ( \frac{1-0.4}{1-0.6} \right )=1.2m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 42 A wastewater is to be disinfected with 35 mg/Lof chlorine to obtain 99% kill of micro-organisms. The number of micro-organisms remaining alive ([latex]N_t[/latex]) at time t, is modelled by [latex]N_t=N_oe^{-kt}[/latex], where [latex]N_o[/latex] is number of micro-organisms at t= 0, and k is the rate of kill. The wastewater flow rate is 36 [latex]m^3/hr[/latex], and k= 0.23 [latex]min^{-1}[/latex]. If the depth and width of the chlorination tank are 1.5 m and 1.0 m, respectively, the length of the tank (in m, round off to 2 decimal places) is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} N_t&=N_0e^{-kt}\\ \therefore \; \eta &=[1-e^{-kt}]100\\ 99&=[1-e^{-0.23\times t}]100\\ \therefore \;t&=20.22min\\ Q&=36m^3/hr\\ V&=Q \times t\\ &=\frac{36}{60}\times 20.22=12.0132\\ \text{Length}&=\frac{V}{B \times H}=\frac{12.0132}{1 \times 1.5}\\ &=8.008\cong 8m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 43 A staff is placed on a benchmark (BM) of reduced level (RL) 100.000 m and a theodolite is placed at a horizontal distance of 50 m from the BM to measure the vertical angles. The measured vertical angles from the horizontal at the staff readings of 0.400 m and 2.400 m are found to be the same. Taking the height of the instrument as 1.400m, the RL (in m) of the theodolite station is _____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x&=50 \tan \alpha \\ 2-x&=50 \tan \alpha \\ \therefore \;\;x&=2-x \\ 2x&=2 \\ x&=1m \end{aligned}[/latex] R.L of theodolite station (P): 100 + 1.4 - 0.1 - 0.4 = 100 m

question: Question 44 Consider the ordinary differential equation [latex]x^2\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}-2x\frac{dy}{dx}+2y=0[/latex]. Given the values of y(1)=0 and y(2)=2, the value of y(3) (round off to 1 decimal place), is ____

Question 45 Average free flow speed and the jam density observed on a roadstretch are 60 km/h and 120 vehicles/km, respectively. For a linear speed-density relationship, the maximum flow on the road stretch (in vehicles/h) is _________
solution: Maximum Speed / Free ?ow speed, [latex]V_m[/latex] = 60 kmph Jam density, [latex]K_m[/latex] = 120 kmph for linear speed - density (Green shield's model) relationship, max. ?ow, is [latex]q_{max}=\frac{k_j}{2}\times \frac{V_f}{2}[/latex] [latex]q_{max}=\frac{120}{2}\times \frac{60}{2}=1800veh/hr[/latex]

question: Question 46 Traffic on a highway is moving at a rate of 360 vehicles per hour at a location. If the number of vehicles arriving on this highway follows Poisson distribution, the probability (round off to 2 decimal places) that the headway between successive vehicles lies between 6 and 10 seconds is ______
solution: [latex]h_1=[/latex] 6 seconds, [latex]h_1=[/latex] 10 seconds given, avg. rate, [latex]\lambda =360\;veh/hr=360\times \frac{1}{3600}=\frac{1}{10}\; veh/sec[/latex] Probability that the headway is between [latex]h_1 \; and \; h_2[/latex] is given by, [latex]\begin{aligned} P(h_1\leq h\leq h_2)&=e^{\lambda h_1}-e^{-\lambda h_2} \\ &= e^{-\frac{1}{10}\times 6}-e^{-\frac{1}{10}\times 10}\\ &= 0.1808\approx 0.18 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 47 A parabolic vertical curve is being designed to join a road of grade +5% with a road of grade -3%. The length of the vertical curve is 400m measured along the horizontal. The vertical point of curvature (VPC) is located on the road of grade +5%. The difference in height between VPC and vertical point of intersection (VPI) (in m, round off to the nearest integer)is _____
solution: Given, [latex]N_1=+5\%,\; N_2=-3\%[/latex] Length of summit curve is, [latex]l = 400 m[/latex] Vertical distance between VPC and VPI is [latex]N_1 \times \frac{l}{2}=\frac{5\%}{100}\times 200=10m[/latex]

question: Question 48 Tie bars of 12 mm diameter are to be provided in a concrete pavement slab. The working tensile stress of the tie bars is 230 MPa, the average bond strength between a tie bar and concrete is 2 MPa, and the joint gap between the slabs is 10 mm. Ignoring the loss of bond and the tolerance factor, the design length of the tie bars (in mm, round off to the nearest integer) is _____
solution: [latex]L_d=\frac{\phi \sigma _{st}}{4\tau _{bd}}=\frac{12 \times 230}{4 \times 2}=345mm[/latex] Length of tie bar [latex]=L_d+10+L_d=345+10+345=700mm[/latex]

question: Question 49 The hyetograph of a storm event of duration 140 minutesis shown in the figure. The infiltration capacity at the start of this event (t=0) is 17 mm/hour, which linearly decreases to 10 mm/hour after 40 minutes duration. As the event progresses, the infiltration rate further drops down linearly to attain a value of 4 mm/hour at t=100 minutes and remains constant thereafter till the end of the storm event. The value of the infiltration index, [latex]\phi[/latex] (in mm/hour, round off to 2 decimal places), is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P&=(4+8+15+10+8+3+1) \times \frac{20}{60} \\ &=16.33\; minute \\ Q&=(15-10) \times \frac{20}{60} +(10-8) \times \frac{20}{60} \\ &+(8-6) \times \frac{20}{60} +\frac{1}{2}\times 2 \times \frac{20}{60}+\frac{1}{2} \\ &+\frac{1}{2}\times 2 \times \frac{20}{60}+frac{1}{2}\times 2 \times \frac{20}{60}\\ &=4mm\\ W-index&=\frac{P-Q}{t}=\frac{16.33-4}{\frac{140}{60}}=5.28 mm/hr\\ \text{Since,} \; \phi & \geq W\\ \text{Assume, }\; \phi &=5.28 mm/hr\\ \Rightarrow \; \text{Corrected, }\phi &=\frac{16.33-4-4 \times \frac{20}{60}-3 \times \frac{20}{60}-1 \times \frac{20}{60}}{\left ( \frac{140-30-20-20}{60} \right )} \\ &=7.2475 mm/hr \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 50 Two water reservoirs are connected by a siphon (running full) of total length 5000 m and diameter of 0.10m, as shown below The inlet leg length of the siphon to its summit is 2000m. The difference in the water surface levels of the two reservoirs is 5 m. Assume the permissible minimum absolute pressure at the summit of siphon to be 2.5 m of water when running full. Given: friction factor f=0.02 throughout, atmospheric pressure= 10.3 m of water, and acceleration due to gravity g= 9.81 [latex]m/s^2[/latex]. Considering only major loss using Darcy-Weisbach equation, the maximum height of the summit of siphon from the water level of upper reservoir,h (in m, round off to 1 decimal place)is _____
solution: Applying Bernoulli's equation between 1 & 3 [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{P_1}{\rho g}+\frac{v_1^2}{2g}+z_1&= \frac{P_3}{\rho g}+\frac{v_3^2}{2g}+z_3+h_{f13}\\ z_1-z_3&=h_{f13}\;\;\;(\because \; P_1=P_3=P_{atm}\; and \; v_1=v_3=0) \\ 5&=\frac{fLv^2}{2gd} \\ v^2&=\frac{5 \times 2\times 9.81\times 0.1}{0.02\times 5000} \\ v&=0.313m/s \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying Bernoulli's equation between 1 & 2 [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{P_1}{\rho g}+\frac{v_1^2}{2g}+z_1&= \frac{P_2}{\rho g}+\frac{v_2^2}{2g}+z_2+h_{f12}\\ 10.3+0+0&=2.5+\frac{0.313^2}{2 \times 9.81}+h+\frac{0.02 \times 2000 \times 0.313^2}{2 \times 9.81 \times 0.1}\\ h&=5.798m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 Consider a laminar flow in the x-direction between two infinite parallel plates (Couette flow). The lower plate is stationary and the upper plate is moving with a velocity of 1 cm/s in the x-direction. The distance between the plates is 5 mm and the dynamic viscosity of the fluid is 0.01 [latex]N-s/m^2[/latex]. If the shear stress on the lower plate is zero, the pressure gradient, [latex]\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}[/latex], (in [latex]N/m^2[/latex] per m,round off to 1 decimal place)is _______
solution: Given fl\ow is a couette flow with pressure gradient [latex]\mu =0.01N-s/m^2[/latex] h=5mm if [latex]\tau _{y=0}=0, \; \text{find}\; \frac{dp}{dx}[/latex] The velocity distribution, for the couette flow with pressure gradient is given by [latex]u=\frac{wy}{h}-\frac{1}{2\mu }\frac{dp}{dx}[hy-y^2][/latex] where w is the velocity of the top plate and h is the gap between the plates [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{du}{dy}&=\frac{w}{h}-\frac{1}{2\mu }\frac{dp}{dx}[h-2y] \\ \left.\begin{matrix} \frac{du}{dy} \end{matrix}\right|_{y=0} &=\frac{w}{h}-\frac{1}{2\mu }\frac{dp}{dx}h \\ \tau _{y=0}&=\mu \left [ \frac{w}{h}-\frac{1}{2\mu }\frac{dp}{dx}h \right ] \\ \tau _{y=0}&=\frac{w\mu }{h}-\frac{1}{2}\frac{dp}{dx}h \\ \text{when}\; \tau _{y=0}&=0, \; \text{we will have}\\ \frac{1}{2}\frac{dp}{dx}h&=\frac{w\mu }{h}\\ \frac{dp}{dx}&=\frac{2w\mu }{h^2} \\ &=\frac{2 \times 1 \times 10^{-2}\times 0.01}{(5 \times 10^{-3})^2} \\ &=8 N/m^2 \; \text{per} \; m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 52 A reinforced concrete circular pile of 12 m length and 0.6 m diameter is embedded in stiff clay which has an undrained unit cohesion of 110 [latex]kN/m^2[/latex]. The adhesion factor is 0.5. The Net Ultimate Pullout (uplift) Load for the pile (in kN, round off to 1 decimal place) is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text{Net Ultimate pullout} \\ &=\alpha CA_s =0.5 \times 110(\pi dL) \\ &=0.5 \times 110(\pi \times 0.6 \times 12)\\&=1244.1kN \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 A granular soil has a saturated unit weight of 20[latex]kN/m^3[/latex] and an effective angle of shearing resistance of 30[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. The unit weight of water is 9.81 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex]. A slope is to be made on this soil deposit in which the seepage occurs parallel to the slope up to the free surface. Under this seepage condition for a factor of safety of 1.5, the safe slope angle (in degree, round off to 1 decimal place) would be _____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma _{sat}&=20kN/m^3\\ \gamma _w&=9.81kN/m^3\\ \therefore \; \gamma '&=\gamma _{sat}-\gamma _w=10.19kN/m^3\\ \therefore \; \phi '&=30^{\circ},\; F=1.5 \end{aligned}[/latex] For infnite slope, the F.O. safety for seepage parallel to the slope in a granular soil (C = 0) is given below [latex]\begin{aligned} F&=\frac{\gamma '}{\gamma _{sat}}\frac{\tan \phi '}{\tan i}\\ 1.5&=\frac{10.19}{20}\frac{\tan 30}{\tan i}\\ i&=11.095 \; \text{say}\; 11.1^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 A 3mx3m square precast reinforced concrete segments to be installed by pushing them through an existing railway embankment for making an underpass as shown in the figure. A reaction arrangement using precast PCC blocks placed on the ground is to be made for the jacks. At each stage, the jacks are required to apply a force of 1875 kN to push the segment. The jacks will react against the rigid steel plate placed against the reaction arrangement. The footprint area of reaction arrangement on natural ground is 37.5 [latex]m^2[/latex]. The unit weight of PCC block is 24 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex]. The properties of the natural ground are: c = 17 kPa; [latex]\phi =25^{\circ}[/latex] and [latex]\gamma =18 kN/m^3[/latex]. Assuming that the reaction arrangement has rough interface and has the same properties that of soil, the factor of safety (round off to 1 decimal place) against shear failure is _____
solution: Weight of Precast PCC block, [latex]W=volume \times \gamma _c=37.5 \times 7.5 \times 24=6750kN[/latex] Shear resistance below the Precast PCC block is, [latex]S = C.A + W\tan \phi[/latex] F.O safety against shear failure, [latex]\begin{aligned} F&=\frac{S}{T} \\ F&=\frac{C.A.+W \tan \phi }{T} \\ &= \frac{C.A.+N \tan \phi }{T}\;\;\; (Since, \; N=W)\\ &= \frac{17 \times 37.5+6750 \times \tan 25^{\circ}}{1875}\\ &= 2.0187\approx 2.0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 55 A square footing of 4 m side is placed at 1 m depth in a sand deposit. The dry unit weight ([latex]\gamma[/latex]) of sand is 15 [latex]kN/m^3[/latex]. This footing has an ultimate bearing capacity of 600 kPa. Consider the depth factors: [latex]d_q=d_\gamma =1.0[/latex] and the bearing capacity factor: [latex]N_\gamma =18.75[/latex]. This footing is placed at a depth of 2m in the same soil deposit. For a factor of safety of 3.0 as per Terzaghi's theory, the safe bearing capacity (in kPa) of this footing would be _______
solution: As per Terzaghi's theory, the ultimate bearing capacity for a square footing considering depth factors: [latex]d_q=d_\gamma =1[/latex] is as follows: [latex]\begin{aligned} q_u&=1.3CN_C+\gamma D_fN_q+0.4\gamma BN_\gamma \\ &\text{For sand,} \\ C&=0 \\ q_u&=\gamma D_fN_q+0.4\gamma BN_\gamma \\ \text{Given:} \\ \gamma &=15kN/m^3 \\ B&=4m \\ N_\gamma &= 18.75\\ &\text{Initial condition: } \\ D_f&= 1m\\ q_u&=600kPa\\ q_u&=\gamma D_fN_q+0.4\gamma BN_\gamma \\ 600&=15 \times 1 \times N_q +0.4 \times 15 \times 4 \times 18.75\\ N_q&=10\\ \text{If}\;\; D_f&=2m, \;\; \text{then,}\\ q_u&=\gamma D_fN_q+0.4\gamma BN_\gamma \\ &=15 \times 2 \times 10 +0.4 \times 15 \times 4 \times 18.75\\ &=750kN/m^2\\ &\text{Net ultimate BC of soil, }\\ q_{nu}&=q_u-\gamma D_f\\ &=750-15 \times 2=720kN/m^2\\ &\text{The gross safe BC or safe BC, }\\ q_s&=\frac{q_{nu}}{F}+\gamma D_f\\ &=\frac{720}{3}+15 \times 2\\ &=270kPa \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 56 The lecture was attended by quite _______ students, so the hall was not very _______
Question 57 They have come a long way in ________ trust among the users.

Question 58 On a horizontal ground, the base of a straight ladder is 6 m away from the base of a vertical pole. The ladder makes an angle of 45 to the horizontal. If the ladder is resting at a point located at one-fifth of the height of the pole from the bottom, the height of the pole is ______ meters.
Question 59 If E=10, J=20, O=30, and T=40, what will be P+E+S+T?
Question 60 The CEO's decision to quit was as shocking to the Board as it was to ______.

Question 61 The new cotton technology, Bollgard-II, with herbicide-tolerant traits has developed into a thriving business in India. However, the commercial use of this technology is not legal in India. Notwithstanding that, reports indicate that the herbicide tolerant Bt cotton had been purchased by farmers at an average of Rs 200 more than the control price of ordinary cotton, and planted in  15% of the cotton growing area in the 2017 Kharif season. Which one of the following statements can be inferred from the given passage?

options.A: Farmers want to access the new technology if India benefits from it
options.B: Farmers want to access the new technology even if it is not legal
options.C: Farmers want to access the new technology for experimental purposes
options.D: Farmers want to access the new technology by paying high price

question: Question 62 In a sports academy of 300 peoples, 105 play only cricket, 70 play only hockey, 50 play only football, 25 play both cricket and hockey, 15 play both hockey and football and 30 play both cricket and football. The rest of them play all three sports. What is the percentage of people who play at least two sports?

Question 63 "The increasing interest in tribal characters might be a mere coincidence, but the timing is of interest. None of this, though, is to say that the tribal hero has arrived in Hindi cinema, or that the new crop of characters represents the acceptance of the tribal character in the industry. The films and characters are too few to be described as a pattern." What does the word 'arrived' mean in the paragraph above?
Question 64 A square has side 5 cm smaller than the sides of a second square. The area of the larger square is four times the area of the smaller square. The side of the larger square is _______ cm.

Question 65 P, Q, R, S and T are related and belong to the same family. P is the brother of S, Q is the wife of P. R and T are the children of the siblings P and S respectively. Which one of the following statement is necessarily FALSE?

options.A: S is the aunt of R
options.B: S is the aunt of T
options.C: S is the sister-in-law of Q
options.D: S is the brother of P
